Name: Accident Prone
Game Effect: Clumsy or unlucky ‚Äì the character frequently causes or suffers accidents. The GM may occasionally introduce slips, falls, or other mishaps affecting the character (and perhaps those nearby) even on marginal successes. Extra care and Edge may be needed to avoid collateral damage.

Name: Achilles' Heel
Game Effect: The character has a specific weakness that dramatically undermines them. (Must specify what it is ‚Äì e.g., ‚ÄúAchilles‚Äô Heel: Arachnophobia‚Äù or ‚ÄúAchilles‚Äô Heel: Cannot swim‚Äù). When faced with this weakness, the character freezes or automatically fails related tests. Enemies who know of this weakness gain +4 Edge or automatically succeed when exploiting it.

Name: Addiction (Substance, 1 to 6)
Game Effect: Character is addicted to a substance or behavior; must indulge regularly or suffer penalties. Karma gain depends on addiction severity.

Name: Affinity for Transit (specific)
Game Effect: Natural aptitude for a particular mode of transportation (e.g., trains, suborbitals, etc.). The character gains +2 dice on tests when operating or navigating that type of transit. (Must specify one form of transit or vehicle type when taking this quality.)

Name: All Business
Game Effect: Serious and humorless. In casual or social situations not directly related to work, the character suffers a penalty (e.g. ‚Äì2 dice) due to their overly professional, cold demeanor.

Name: Allergy (Common/Extreme)
Game Effect: Character has an allergic reaction to a specific substance; exposure causes harm or penalties. Karma depends on allergen rarity and severity of reaction.

Name: Allergy (Common/Mild)
Game Effect: Character has an allergic reaction to a specific substance; exposure causes harm or penalties. Karma depends on allergen rarity and severity of reaction.

Name: Allergy (Common/Moderate)
Game Effect: Character has an allergic reaction to a specific substance; exposure causes harm or penalties. Karma depends on allergen rarity and severity of reaction.

Name: Allergy (Common/Severe)
Game Effect: Character has an allergic reaction to a specific substance; exposure causes harm or penalties. Karma depends on allergen rarity and severity of reaction.

Name: Allergy (Rare/Extreme)
Game Effect: Character has an allergic reaction to a specific substance; exposure causes harm or penalties. Karma depends on allergen rarity and severity of reaction.

Name: Allergy (Rare/Mild)
Game Effect: Character has an allergic reaction to a specific substance; exposure causes harm or penalties. Karma depends on allergen rarity and severity of reaction.

Name: Allergy (Rare/Moderate)
Game Effect: Character has an allergic reaction to a specific substance; exposure causes harm or penalties. Karma depends on allergen rarity and severity of reaction.

Name: Allergy (Rare/Severe)
Game Effect: Character has an allergic reaction to a specific substance; exposure causes harm or penalties. Karma depends on allergen rarity and severity of reaction.

Name: Allergy (Seasonal/Extreme)
Game Effect: Character has an allergic reaction to a specific substance; exposure causes harm or penalties. Karma depends on allergen rarity and severity of reaction.

Name: Allergy (Seasonal/Mild)
Game Effect: Character has an allergic reaction to a specific substance; exposure causes harm or penalties. Karma depends on allergen rarity and severity of reaction.

Name: Allergy (Seasonal/Moderate)
Game Effect: Character has an allergic reaction to a specific substance; exposure causes harm or penalties. Karma depends on allergen rarity and severity of reaction.

Name: Allergy (Seasonal/Severe)
Game Effect: Character has an allergic reaction to a specific substance; exposure causes harm or penalties. Karma depends on allergen rarity and severity of reaction.

Name: Allergy (Uncommon/Extreme)
Game Effect: Character has an allergic reaction to a specific substance; exposure causes harm or penalties. Karma depends on allergen rarity and severity of reaction.

Name: Allergy (Uncommon/Mild)
Game Effect: Character has an allergic reaction to a specific substance; exposure causes harm or penalties. Karma depends on allergen rarity and severity of reaction.

Name: Allergy (Uncommon/Moderate)
Game Effect: Character has an allergic reaction to a specific substance; exposure causes harm or penalties. Karma depends on allergen rarity and severity of reaction.

Name: Allergy (Uncommon/Severe)
Game Effect: Character has an allergic reaction to a specific substance; exposure causes harm or penalties. Karma depends on allergen rarity and severity of reaction.

Name: Always Ready
Game Effect: Prepared for action at a moment‚Äôs notice. The character gains a bonus to Initiative or surprise tests ‚Äì they are far less likely to be caught off-guard, often acting in the first phase of combat even when others would be surprised.

Name: Ambidextrous
Game Effect: No off-hand penalty for using the secondary hand in combat or tasks.

Name: Analytical Mind
Game Effect: Gains an Edge or bonus when using Logic-based skills (reflecting an excellent analytical ability).

Name: AR Vertigo
Game Effect: Augmented Reality makes the character dizzy or uncomfortable. They suffer a penalty when using AR visual overlays or take longer to adapt to AR environments.

Name: Arcane Resilience Training
Game Effect: The magician uses a different mental attribute for Drain resistance than normal. Allows the character to define Logic, Intuition, or Charisma as their tradition‚Äôs Drain Attribute instead of the default Willpower.

Name: Astral Chameleon
Game Effect: Astral signature fades twice as fast, making the character harder to track magically.

Name: At Home in the Matrix
Game Effect: The character is completely comfortable in virtual environments. They suffer no penalties for prolonged Matrix usage (no ‚Äúnoise‚Äù from mental fatigue) and recover from VR-related disorientation or dumpshock more quickly than others.

Name: Attribute Mastery (Determination)
Game Effect: Gives an Edge benefit for a chosen attribute‚Äôs linked skills (similar to Analytical Mind but for a different Attribute). **Determination:** for example, if applied to Willpower-linked skills, the character gains +1 Edge on a test (once per round) when using skills linked to Willpower.

Name: Augmentation Acclimation (1-10)
Game Effect: Character‚Äôs body adapts to heavy cyberware; each level frees up 0.1 Essence for cyberware without raising Essence loss (requires Essence 3 or lower to take).

Name: Bad Back
Game Effect: Chronic back problems. The character has trouble with heavy lifting or sustained physical exertion. They suffer penalties on strenuous physical tasks and might need to rest more often or risk injury when overexerting.

Name: Bad Luck
Game Effect: Extremely unlucky; uses of Edge may backfire or critical glitches occur more frequently for the character.

Name: Bermuda Gremlins
Game Effect: A strange tech curse haunts the character. Particularly when traveling or in unusual locales, their vehicles and devices experience bizarre malfunctions (navigation errors, sensor ghosts) reminiscent of the Bermuda Triangle. This can disrupt travel plans and require extra diagnostics to fix.

Name: Binary Mentality
Game Effect: The character thinks in rigid binaries and struggles with nuance. They take ‚Äì2 on social tests requiring empathy or deception (since they are too blunt or literal) and may misinterpret sarcasm or complex motives. Their planning is very all-or-nothing, which the GM can exploit with moral dilemmas or ambiguous situations.

Name: Blandness
Game Effect: Character is nondescript and easily forgotten; others suffer penalties to notice or remember them.

Name: Borrowed Time
Game Effect: Doom hangs over the character‚Äîthey have only a limited time to live (terminal condition or curse). The GM secretly determines when the clock runs out; the character is living on borrowed time, which creates urgent personal goals.

Name: Bounty
Game Effect: A price on your head. There is an active bounty for capturing or killing the character. Bounty hunters or interested parties will come after them during play, forcing the character to remain in hiding or deal with constant threats.

Name: Bravado
Game Effect: Daring and fearless, thriving in the spotlight. The character gains an Edge or bonus when performing audacious or flashy actions in dangerous situations.

Name: Brilliant Heuristics
Game Effect: The character‚Äôs logical problem-solving ability (or coding algorithms) is exceptional. They gain +2 dice on tests to analyze complex data or solve Matrix puzzles (like cracking encryption or optimizing code on the fly).

Name: Buddy System
Game Effect: The character hates operating alone. If they don‚Äôt have an ally nearby, they suffer ‚Äì2 dice on skill tests due to anxiety or lack of confidence. They will actively seek out a partner or insist on backup, and going solo even for short periods requires a Composure (Willpower + Charisma) test.

Name: Bull in a China Shop
Game Effect: The character is extremely clumsy in the Matrix. Their hacking attempts often set off alarms or cause collateral damage. Any time the character rolls a Matrix test and gets 2 or more 1s (even if not a glitch), an unintended consequence occurs (like triggering an alert or damaging a file they didn‚Äôt intend to). Subtlety is not their strong suit ‚Äì Opposed Matrix tests to detect them gain +2 dice.

Name: Chronic Pain
Game Effect: Constant pain (from an old injury or illness) plagues the character. They suffer periodic penalties (e.g. ‚Äì2 dice) on actions when the pain flares up, and may require medication or stimulants to function normally.

Name: Combat Junkie
Game Effect: Addicted to the adrenaline of combat. The character must succeed at a Willpower test to avoid initiating or prolonging fights unnecessarily. They may take reckless actions in combat just for the thrill, even when tactics call for retreat or stealth.

Name: Combat Paralysis
Game Effect: Freezes or hesitates in combat; suffers initiative penalties or loss of actions during the first round of any combat encounter.

Name: Compulsive Archivist
Game Effect: Obsessed with hoarding information. The character cannot bring themselves to delete data or pass up the opportunity to collect new information. They must succeed at a Willpower test to not download a tempting paydata file or to purge old files. Their devices are filled with logs/backups (risk if seized), and they often delay in missions to ‚Äújust grab‚Äù extra data.

Name: Critter Dominator
Game Effect: Exudes dominance over animals/critters. The character can attempt to cow a non-sapient critter with a Major Action, compelling it to submission (resisted by the critter‚Äôs Willpower).

Name: Critter Trainer
Game Effect: Skilled at taming and training animals. The character can tame wild critters (over time with tests) and train them to follow commands more effectively than a normal trainer.

Name: Curiosity Killed the Cat
Game Effect: Overwhelming curiosity. When confronted with an unknown or mysterious situation (especially in the Matrix, like a strange icon or encrypted node), the character must make a Willpower test to avoid investigating it immediately, even if it‚Äôs dangerous. Failure means they will poke around or open the file/trap despite warnings.

Name: Cyber Psychosis
Game Effect: Diminished empathy from extreme cyber augmentation. The character has trouble relating to others; they may receive social penalties and must make Willpower tests to resist violent or unempathetic impulses. (Often taken by characters with very low Essence.)

Name: Cyberjack Maximization
Game Effect: Expert in cyberdeck tuning. Adds +1 to the lower of the two Matrix attributes of the character‚Äôs cyberjack (increasing overall deck performance).

Name: Cyborg
Game Effect: Extensive cyber integration. For characters with Essence 1 or less who already maxed Augmentation Acclimation, each level frees an additional 0.1 Essence for augmentations (beyond normal limits).
Requirements: Essence ‚â§ 1 and 10 levels of Augmentation Acclimation

Name: Data Anomaly
Game Effect: The character‚Äôs data trail is strangely erratic. Matrix Perception checks to trace or identify the character‚Äôs icon suffer ‚Äì2 dice, as if something about their persona‚Äôs code doesn‚Äôt conform to expected patterns.

Name: Data Haven Membership
Game Effect: The character belongs to an exclusive data haven (secret Matrix community). This grants access to hidden forums, paydata exchanges, and off-the-grid resources. (In game terms, they might start with a useful contact in the haven and easier access to certain knowledge or illegal files.)

Name: Data Liberator
Game Effect: Ideological hacker who believes information should be free. The character feels compelled to release stolen data to the public rather than sell it or keep it secret. After completing a run involving valuable data, they must make a Charisma + Willpower test to refrain from leaking it. They may also refuse runs that involve suppressing or destroying data, and prefer runs where data is exposed.

Name: Dead Stick
Game Effect: Intermittent control loss. Occasionally (especially on a glitch), the character‚Äôs vehicle controls become unresponsive (‚Äúgo dead‚Äù). The character must succeed on a Piloting test to regain control, or the vehicle will continue on its last input (potentially causing a crash or stall).

Name: Deck Builder
Game Effect: Talented at building and customizing cyberdecks. The character gains +2 dice on Hardware tests to modify or repair cyberdecks. They can also jury-rig temporary deck boosts more safely (e.g., overclocking a deck has a lower chance of frying it).

Name: Defective Attribute (Matrix)
Game Effect: One of the character‚Äôs Matrix persona attributes is flawed (Attack, Sleaze, Data Processing, or Firewall ‚Äì choose one when taking this quality). In practice, that attribute functions as 1 point lower than its listed value for all purposes (defense, limit, etc.). The character‚Äôs persona has a built-in weakness that savvy opponents can exploit.

Name: Distinctive Style
Game Effect: Character has memorable features or habits (appearance, tattoos, etc.), making them easier to notice and remember (+2 dice for others to recognize/track them).

Name: Double-Jointed
Game Effect: Flexible joints allow the character to escape bonds or fit into tight spaces with ease (bonuses to such tests).

Name: Driving Style: Combat Ace
Game Effect: Specialized driving style focusing on vehicular combat. The character halves the Edge cost for attack maneuvers in vehicle combat (e.g., ramming or firing while driving) and gains a bonus when performing aggressive driving tactics.

Name: Driving Style: Getaway Driver
Game Effect: Specialized in escape and evasion driving. Halves Edge cost for maneuvers related to fleeing pursuers or losing tails. The character excels at quick turns, brake tricks, and other getaway tactics, making high-speed escapes smoother.

Name: Driving Style: Interceptor
Game Effect: Specialized in intercepting and blocking targets. Halves Edge cost for maneuvers intended to cut off or corner another vehicle in a chase. The character gets bonuses when attempting pit maneuvers or forming roadblocks with their vehicle.

Name: Driving Style: Reckless Driver
Game Effect: High-risk, high-reward driving style. Halves Edge cost for performing dangerous stunts (jumps, near-crashes) with a vehicle. The character is adept at pushing vehicles beyond safe limits, often gaining Edge when attempting extremely hazardous maneuvers.

Name: Driving Style: Stunt Driver
Game Effect: Specialized in precision driving and theatrical stunts. Halves Edge cost for complex vehicular maneuvers (e.g., tight slaloms, 360¬∫ spins). The character can perform spectacular tricks with greater control and may receive bonuses to entertain or distract using vehicle maneuvers.

Name: Drone Animosity
Game Effect: Drones and AIs just don‚Äôt like you. Autopilots target the character preferentially, and free drones or sprites react negatively. The character suffers a ‚Äì2 dice penalty on social tests toward AI or drone entities, and enemy drones may choose them as a primary target more often.

Name: Easy Mark
Game Effect: Gullible and easily conned. The character resists Con and social manipulation with ‚Äì2 dice. NPC grifters or hustlers will often single them out as a target. (The character might also have a hard time saying ‚Äúno‚Äù to sob stories or sales pitches.)

Name: Fade to Black
Game Effect: Expert at covering tracks in the Matrix. When the character logs off or crashes a host, their Overwatch Score is reduced by an additional amount (or increases more slowly). It‚Äôs much harder for GOD to pinpoint their activities; convergence is effectively delayed or requires more OS against them.

Name: Finesse
Game Effect: Prefers subtlety over brute force, to a fault. The character cannot gain or spend Edge on actions that rely on brute strength or direct aggression, as such tactics unnerve them. They are compelled to use stealth or clever approaches even when not ideal.

Name: First Impression
Game Effect: Excellent at initial meetings; +2 dice on social tests when meeting someone new (only on the first encounter).

Name: Fractal Blast
Game Effect: The character‚Äôs Matrix attacks (especially technomancer complex forms or biofeedback attacks) have a chaotic fractal signature that‚Äôs hard to defend against. Once per encounter, they can force a target defending against their Matrix attack to take a ‚Äì2 dice penalty (representing the unpredictable code pattern).

Name: Fuzz Magnet
Game Effect: Attracts law enforcement attention. Police and security seem to zero in on the character for random stops, searches, and ID checks. The character‚Äôs ‚Äúheat‚Äù or Notoriety among law enforcement is effectively higher ‚Äì they might get recognized or hassled even when doing nothing wrong.

Name: Gear Acquisition Syndrome
Game Effect: Obsessed with obtaining new gear. The character compulsively spends resources on the latest gadgets or weapons. They may have to make a Willpower test to resist purchasing new tech, often leaving them short on cash.

Name: Glitchy
Game Effect: Personal tech prone to errors. One of the character‚Äôs important devices or cyberware pieces frequently glitches. The GM may trigger a minor glitch at inconvenient times (even on a successful roll) for that device.

Name: Golden Screwdriver
Game Effect: Master debugger. The character gets +2 dice on tests to troubleshoot or debug Matrix systems (e.g., fixing a glitched program, clearing a virus, repairing a corrupted file). They also halve the time needed to fix Matrix errors or restore a crashed device.

Name: Gourmand
Game Effect: Finicky eater who can only tolerate high-quality or specific foods. The character must pay extra for gourmet meals or suffer discomfort and penalties (malnutrition or distraction) if forced to consume standard fare.

Name: Grease Monkey (Engineering)
Game Effect: Expert mechanic for vehicles and drones. +2 dice on Engineering tests to repair or modify vehicles/drones, and maintenance takes less time. The character likely has a knack for jury-rigging fixes in the field to keep machines running.

Name: Gremlins (Level 1-4)
Game Effect: Technology tends to malfunction around the character. Any device they use has an increased chance to glitch or critically glitch (higher levels intensify this effect).

Name: Hacker Combo
Game Effect: Capable of executing two Matrix actions in quick succession. Once per Combat Turn, the character may perform two Matrix actions that normally each require a Major Action, as a combined Major Action (e.g., a hack followed immediately by editing data). The second action might receive a +1 Threshold or ‚Äì2 dice (since combo actions are tricky), but it allows complex hacking sequences in one go.

Name: Hold the Door
Game Effect: Specialist in holding open or preventing system shutdowns. If a host is trying to expel the character or go on lockdown, the character gains +2 dice to resist it and can extend the time before a forced log-off or door lock closes by one round. (In Matrix terms, they keep an access node open longer for teammates to escape or enter.)

Name: Honorbound (Code of Honor)
Game Effect: The character adheres to a strict personal code (defined with the GM ‚Äì e.g. never harm innocents, always keep one‚Äôs word). They must act according to this code at all times. Breaking it is extraordinarily difficult (likely requiring spending Edge or a Willpower (very high) test) and would result in intense personal guilt and possibly gamemaster-imposed consequences.

Name: Hooder
Game Effect: Robin Hood syndrome: the character feels compelled to aid the downtrodden, even at personal cost. They often give away a portion of earnings to help others or refuse runs that go against their moral code. (Similar to a mild Code of Honor focused on helping the poor.)

Name: Hunted
Game Effect: A particular individual or organization is actively hunting the character. This hunter is persistent and personal (unlike a general bounty). The character will face attempts on their life or freedom throughout the campaign until the issue is resolved.

Name: ICU (‚ÄúI See You‚Äù)
Game Effect: The character is very good at spotting hidden icons and cyber-threats. They gain +2 dice on Matrix Perception tests to observe silent running icons, spot IC or traps in hosts, and notice Marks on personas. (Nothing on the Matrix escapes their notice easily.)

Name: Impenetrable Logic
Game Effect: The character‚Äôs logic (or Firewall coding) is extremely strong. When resisting Matrix actions targeting their devices or persona (like resisting a hack or data spike), they gain +2 dice on defense if the test is linked to Logic. Additionally, if using a cyberdeck, their Firewall counts as 1 higher for determining if a hacker gets a mark on them.

Name: In Debt (•5,000 per level)
Game Effect: Character begins play owing money to a creditor. They receive extra starting funds but must pay off the debt (plus interest) during gameplay.

Name: Indecisive
Game Effect: Difficulty making decisions under pressure. The character may lose initiative or waste actions second-guessing. (GM might enforce an initiative score reduction or require extra Minor Actions before the character chooses a course in combat.)

Name: Injury Prone
Game Effect: The character tends to get hurt more often or severely. Whenever they take Physical damage, they might take an extra box of damage (or have a higher chance of a lingering injury). Essentially, they bruise easy and suffer mishaps that others might avoid.

Name: Jack Jockey
Game Effect: Expert at direct connections. The character can jack into devices quickly and effectively. Plugging in a wired connection to a device is a Free Action for them, and they gain +1 Edge on the first test made via a direct wired connection (because they know how to exploit physical access).

Name: Junkyard King
Game Effect: Master of scavenging parts. The character can always seem to find the component they need in scrapyards or among junk. They gain a bonus to scavenging tests and can once per session locate a needed vehicle/drone part or mod for free (GM‚Äôs discretion).

Name: Killer
Game Effect: Whether by reputation or inclination, the character is known as a killer. They may take a psychological compulsion to use lethal force (Willpower test to use non-lethal options), and suffer social stigma ‚Äì law enforcement and shadows alike treat them as particularly dangerous.

Name: Like a Boss
Game Effect: The character has a need to show off and be in charge, often at inappropriate times. They might try to one-up allies or make grandiose displays that draw attention. In stealth situations, they have to make a Willpower test to avoid a flashy move or quip that could blow cover. Socially, their ego can rub people wrong ‚Äì +2 TN on Etiquette tests in formal or subordinate roles (they don‚Äôt ‚Äúknow their place‚Äù).

Name: Limited Attributes
Game Effect: One of the character‚Äôs attributes has a reduced maximum. (Specify the attribute when taking this quality.) The chosen attribute‚Äôs natural and augmented limits are each 1 point lower than normal for the character‚Äôs metatype.

Name: Limited Skills
Game Effect: The character has a cap on certain skills. (Pick a skill category or group when taken.) Skills in that group cannot exceed a certain rating (e.g., cannot raise above 3 at chargen or above 6 overall), reflecting a ceiling on their talent in that area.

Name: Loonet
Game Effect: (Low Orbit Optic Network Enthusiast / ‚ÄúLooney‚Äù) ‚Äì The character is plugged into the latest Matrix subcultures and trends. They gain +2 dice on Etiquette or Con tests in online forums and might have a minor degree of Matrix celebrity. This online fame can be leveraged for information or favors among the Matrix community.

Name: Magic Resistance (1-3)
Game Effect: Inherent resistance to sorcery; +1 die per level to resist spells (cannot voluntarily accept beneficial spells).

Name: Martial Arts Prodigy
Game Effect: Natural talent for martial arts. The character gains additional benefits when learning or using martial art techniques (such as reduced Karma cost or an extra technique at character creation).

Name: Maximum Overdrive
Game Effect: Can push cyberware beyond safe limits. Each level extends the duration of Augmentation Overdrive (cyberware boosting ability) by 1 combat round (instead of a single test; wild die still applies).

Name: Mentor Spirit
Game Effect: Gain the benefits (and drawbacks) of a mentor spirit (totem), such as bonus dice to certain magic tasks and roleplaying guidance.

Name: Mode Lock
Game Effect: The character is effectively ‚Äúlocked‚Äù into one mode of Matrix interaction. Choose one: *AR-Only:* They cannot go full VR (or suffer extreme penalties if they try). *VR-Only:* They can‚Äôt effectively operate in AR ‚Äì they must be in hot-sim to do anything useful (maybe due to BTL addiction). In their non-preferred mode, they take ‚Äì4 on all Matrix actions.

Name: Momentous Misfortune
Game Effect: If something can go wrong, it will ‚Äì especially at a dramatic moment. Once per game (at GM‚Äôs discretion), a critical failure or twist of fate will strike the character at the worst time, even if they seemingly did everything right.

Name: More Machine than Metahuman
Game Effect: The character‚Äôs cybernetic enhancements are so extensive they can be ‚Äúrepaired‚Äù like a machine. They can be healed with the Engineering skill (mechanics) as if they were a vehicle (magical healing on them is less effective).

Name: Motion Sickness
Game Effect: Susceptible to motion-induced nausea. The character takes a ‚Äì2 penalty on actions when riding in fast-moving vehicles or if subjected to sudden motion (including VR simsense if not acclimated). They may need to make a Body + Willpower test to avoid vomiting or becoming incapacitated during turbulent travel.

Name: Muscles
Game Effect: Exceptional physical development. At character creation, the character may have up to two Physical attributes at their metatype maximum (normally, only one attribute can be at max).

Name: Natural Hacker
Game Effect: Innate talent for hacking. The character gains +1 Edge on the first illegal Matrix action they attempt each encounter (hack on the fly, crack file, etc.) if they have no assistance (acting solo without an agent or sprite). They also improve hacking-related skills at half Karma cost (GM‚Äôs discretion on which skills).

Name: Non-Lethal
Game Effect: Aversion to lethal violence. The character refuses to intentionally kill. They stick to stun damage and non-lethal methods wherever possible. If they inadvertently kill or are pressured to use lethal force, they suffer stress and possible penalties until they atone.

Name: Perforated Firewall
Game Effect: One of the character‚Äôs devices has a known security vulnerability. Hackers get +1 on tests to mark or hack that device/icon. The character might start with a low Firewall commlink or cyberdeck that is ‚Äúleaky,‚Äù and until upgraded, GOD and enemy hackers find it easier to spot or breach.

Name: Polyglot
Game Effect: Flair for languages. Learns new languages quickly and may know a number of additional languages at conversational fluency without tests.

Name: Possession Tradition
Game Effect: The conjurer‚Äôs tradition only allows spirits to possess rather than materialize. Any spirit the character summons has the Materialization power replaced by Possession. This limits the spirit to acting through hosts or vessels instead of manifesting freely.

Name: Prejudiced (Group)
Game Effect: Character holds a strong prejudice against a specific group (metatype, ethnicity, etc.). This bias can cause social penalties and may compel the character to act unfavorably toward the target group. (Karma gain depends on severity: Bias or outright Hatred).

Name: Profiler
Game Effect: Skilled at analyzing personas and patterns. Given some interaction or data from a target (like observing them in the Matrix for a while), the character can ‚Äúprofile‚Äù that user. They gain +2 dice on future opposed tests against that target in the Matrix (as they‚Äôve learned their habits), and may even glean real-world information about them from their Matrix behavior.

Name: Program Dependency
Game Effect: The character relies on a particular cyberprogram or assistant agent for their hacking. Without it, they are significantly less effective. (Choose a program.) If that program isn‚Äôt running, the character takes ‚Äì2 dice on all Matrix actions it would normally assist. Additionally, if the program crashes or is unavailable, the character may need to spend Edge to jury-rig an alternative or suffer a glitch on their next action.

Name: Pusillanimous Summoner
Game Effect: Cowardly summoner. Whenever the character summons a spirit, they are so in awe (or fear) that the spirit tries to twist their words. Spirits the character conjures will follow commands only to the letter (or less). To avoid loopholes, the summoner must first spend time (Conjuring + Intuition [8, 5 min] Extended Test) carefully wording their orders.

Name: Quick Config
Game Effect: The character can reconfigure their cyberdeck on the fly with ease. Switching the allocation of cyberdeck attributes or swapping out a program is a Minor Action (instead of Major). This allows them to adapt their deck setup in the middle of a Matrix encounter without wasting significant time.

Name: Quick Healer
Game Effect: Heals more quickly than normal; +2 dice on Healing tests made on or by the character.

Name: Relentless Tracker
Game Effect: Unyielding focus on a chosen goal or target. With GM approval, the character sets a personal goal (e.g. catching a specific fugitive); they may substitute one die with two Wild Dice on tests made directly in pursuit of that goal. They can choose a new goal once the previous one is achieved.

Name: Remote Pilot
Game Effect: Over-reliance on remote operation. The character has difficulty when directly controlling vehicles (meat space driving) ‚Äì they prefer jumped-in or Rigged control. They suffer ‚Äì2 dice on manual Piloting tests when not jumped in. Conversely, if they normally drive in person, they might have trouble when Rigger-jumped (apply penalty in that case, depending on character‚Äôs usual mode).

Name: Representation I
Game Effect: The magician requires a clear gesture, chant, or special garb to perform magic (chosen when taking this quality). **Level I:** If they cannot use their chosen representation, they suffer ‚Äì4 dice on all Magic tests. **Level II:** They cannot use magic at all without the representation. Using the representation (when available) grants +1 Edge (once per day) on a Magic test. The obvious ritual also makes them an obvious target to enemies.

Name: Representation II
Game Effect: The magician requires a clear gesture, chant, or special garb to perform magic (chosen when taking this quality). **Level I:** If they cannot use their chosen representation, they suffer ‚Äì4 dice on all Magic tests. **Level II:** They cannot use magic at all without the representation. Using the representation (when available) grants +1 Edge (once per day) on a Magic test. The obvious ritual also makes them an obvious target to enemies.

Name: Resonance Burn
Game Effect: Technomancer only. The character‚Äôs Resonance has been scarred (perhaps by dissonant feedback or a dangerous echo). Their Resonance attribute maximum is permanently reduced by 1 (and their current Resonance is reduced accordingly), **or** they suffer +2 DV from Fading on all Complex Forms (GM‚Äôs choice or as defined in the quality). Additionally, certain Resonance actions might cause them pain (e.g., taking 1 Stun when compiling a sprite).
Requirements: This quality is only for Technomancers (Emerged)

Name: Reverberant
Game Effect: A technomancer with a unique Resonance attunement (possibly bordering on Dissonance). This quality might grant access to a specific echo or a bonus when resisting Dissonance-based effects. For example, the character might take 2 less DV from fading when threading certain complex forms, or gain an intuitive sense when Dissonant entities are nearby. *(Exact effect of this quality is defined in context ‚Äì it represents a deep, unusual Resonance trait.)*

Name: Road Rage
Game Effect: Anger issues behind the wheel. When driving and provoked (someone cuts them off, traffic jam, an enemy escapes), the character must make a Willpower test to avoid flying into a rage. Failing means they engage in aggressive driving or chase behavior even if it endangers the mission or themselves.

Name: Rote Alchemist
Game Effect: Extensive practice with alchemical formulas. The character can prepare a specific alchemical formula faster or with fewer materials, or even memorize one formula for quick creation without a recipe.

Name: Satisfaction
Game Effect: The character gains personal satisfaction from successful hacks, fueling their focus. After succeeding at a significant Matrix feat (like successfully extracting paydata or beating a challenging host), they regain 1 spent Edge (once per run) due to the confidence boost. Essentially, their morale and sharpness improve when they pull off a big hack.

Name: Sensitive System
Game Effect: Body rejects cyberware/bioware; Essence cost of any implant is doubled for this character.

Name: Shamanic Mask
Game Effect: When using magic, the character manifests a visible aura or feature related to their mentor spirit/totem (e.g., a ghostly animal mask or elemental effect). By taking a Minor Action while using a Magical skill or power, they gain +1 Edge on that test. Drawback: the mask makes it obvious who the mage is, potentially drawing enemy fire (‚Äúshoot the mage first‚Äù).

Name: Signature Maneuver
Game Effect: The character has a trademark vehicular stunt or maneuver they‚Äôve perfected. When performing their signature move (defined when taking this quality), they gain a significant bonus ‚Äì such as +2 dice or a free Edge ‚Äì because it‚Äôs second nature to them.

Name: Silver Lining
Game Effect: Even when things go wrong, the character manages to find a small benefit. When the character glitches (but doesn‚Äôt critically glitch) on a test, they gain a minor consolation ‚Äì e.g. +1 Edge or a clue from the GM ‚Äì as a ‚Äúsilver lining‚Äù to the failure.

Name: Simsense Dependency
Game Effect: Hooked on the full sensory experience of simsense. The character must regularly immerse in VR or BTLs. If they go more than 24 hours without a hot-sim experience, they suffer ‚Äì1 to all actions (increasing by 1 each additional day, up to ‚Äì3) due to craving/withdrawal. They will prioritize getting their ‚Äúfix‚Äù over some obligations, which can complicate runs.

Name: Simsense Vertigo
Game Effect: Character becomes disoriented or nauseated when using VR/simsense. They suffer penalties on Matrix actions in VR and may need to make Willpower tests to avoid disconnecting.

Name: SINner (Corporate)
Game Effect: Character has (or had) a corporate SIN. They are owned by or closely monitored by a megacorporation, which may demand obedience or punish defection; also easily identified in corp systems.

Name: SINner (Criminal)
Game Effect: Character has a criminal SIN (record of criminal conviction). They face discrimination, increased law enforcement scrutiny, and other legal penalties tied to their record.

Name: SINner (National)
Game Effect: Character has a valid national SIN (System Identification Number). They are in official databases, which can make it easier for authorities or corporations to track and find them.

Name: Sloppy Coder
Game Effect: The character writes inefficient, messy code. Any program or sprite they compile has a quirk: reduce its effective rating by 1 for determining results, or it carries a bug that the GM can invoke once per session (like temporarily crashing or doing something unintended). Opponents trying to exploit the character‚Äôs self-made code gain +1 on their tests.

Name: Software Optimization
Game Effect: Tweaks code for peak performance. One of the character‚Äôs self-written or customized programs (or agents) runs at improved efficiency, granting a bonus (e.g. +1 rating or lower chance of glitching).

Name: Soothing Static
Game Effect: Technomancer can quell digital noise. Reduces the Noise rating by a certain amount in the character‚Äôs vicinity or when threading complex forms, making actions easier in high-noise areas.

Name: Sore Thumb
Game Effect: Stands out in a crowd (or on the grid). The character‚Äôs vehicle or Matrix icon is highly conspicuous ‚Äì maybe painted bright colors or with a loud signature. In any group, they are the easiest to spot or remember. Enemies receive +2 on Perception or Matrix checks to single out the character‚Äôs vehicle or icon among others.

Name: Specialist
Game Effect: Over-specialized at the expense of general ability. The character excels only in a narrow field. Choose a skill category (e.g., Firearms, or Electronics); all skills outside that category suffer +1 Threshold or ‚Äì2 dice when the character uses them, reflecting their one-track training.

Name: Speed Racer
Game Effect: Lives for high-speed driving. The character gains +2 dice on tests to control a vehicle at high speeds and +1 Edge when pushing a vehicle to its top speed. They can handle breakneck velocity maneuvers with greater stability than most drivers.

Name: Spell Components
Game Effect: Efficient use of magical reagents. The magician can use reagents or special components to reduce Drain or enhance spellcasting in a specific way defined by this quality.

Name: Spirit Affinity (Type)
Game Effect: A particular spirit type favors the character; +2 dice on tests to summon or bind that spirit type, and spirits of that type are more well-disposed.

Name: Stim Patch Allergy
Game Effect: Allergic reaction to stimulant patches. Using a stim patch (or similar combat drug patch) on the character causes adverse effects (damage or severe side effects) instead of the normal benefits. They must rely on other means to recover from stun or fatigue.

Name: Surgical Strike
Game Effect: The character‚Äôs Matrix attacks are precise and minimize collateral damage. When performing a Data Spike or other offensive Matrix action, they can choose to do so ‚Äúsurgically,‚Äù imposing a ‚Äì2 dice penalty on themselves *but* causing their attack to not trigger any active alert if it fails. In addition, when targeting a specific device function or sub-system, they ignore 1 point of target‚Äôs Firewall (their strikes hit the weak spot).

Name: Target Fixation
Game Effect: Tends to lock onto a single target in combat to the exclusion of other threats. If the character is chasing or attacking a target, they suffer ‚Äì2 Perception to notice new enemies or hazards. They must make a Willpower test to break off pursuit of a designated target, even when it‚Äôs prudent to do so.

Name: Team Player
Game Effect: Excellent at assisting allies. The character can use a Major Action to make a Leadership + Charisma test to assist a teammate‚Äôs test; either the helper or the assisted ally (player‚Äôs choice) gains +1 Edge from this teamwork.

Name: Teflon Coated
Game Effect: Hard to pin blame on. The character tends to avoid the consequences of their actions; evidence and accusations just ‚Äúdon‚Äôt stick.‚Äù (Mechanically, others receive penalties on tests to trace or place blame on the character for wrongdoing.)

Name: The Motorpool
Game Effect: Access to a collection of vehicles. The character effectively has a ‚Äúfleet‚Äù or easy access to multiple vehicles. They might maintain extra vehicles without lifestyle cost or call upon a network to borrow a specific ride for a job. (GM and player determine exact benefits.)

Name: Toughness
Game Effect: Physically resilient; gains a bonus die on Body tests to resist damage.

Name: Toxin Susceptibility (Specific)
Game Effect: Especially vulnerable to a certain toxin or drug (specified upon taking this quality). The character suffers ‚Äì2 dice to resist that substance and its effects last longer or hit harder than normal.

Name: Trust Issues
Game Effect: Burned by betrayal too often. The character cannot gain or spend Edge from teamwork tests (they never fully trust allies). They also suffer a penalty on Leadership or assist actions when others try to help them, due to their constant suspicion.

Name: Twitchy
Game Effect: Jumpy and on-edge. The character is easily startled and may overreact to surprises. They might automatically enter combat rounds when surprised and suffer ‚Äì1 to initiative as they are constantly tense and jittery.

Name: Uncouth
Game Effect: Lacks basic social skills. Cannot default on Social tests and pays double Karma for improving social skills. The character often behaves inappropriately or awkwardly in social situations.

Name: Underdog
Game Effect: Excels when outmatched in vehicle chases. If the character‚Äôs vehicle is significantly slower or less agile than an opponent‚Äôs, they gain +1 Edge or a bonus die due to their ability to exploit being the underdog (surprising the pursuer with clever driving).

Name: Uneducated
Game Effect: Lacks basic education. Cannot default on technical, academic, or knowledge skills and must spend double Karma to learn or improve them. The character is ignorant of many common facts.

Name: Vehicle Empathy (Pilot Spec)
Game Effect: The character has an intuitive connection with a particular class of vehicles (choose one specialization: e.g., Groundcraft, Aircraft, Drones, etc.). They receive +2 dice on Pilot tests with that type of vehicle and +1 Edge on tests when truly pushing that vehicle to its limits.

Name: Voider of Warranties
Game Effect: The character isn‚Äôt afraid to push hardware beyond recommended settings. They can overclock or jury-rig devices for short-term gains. Once per session, they may boost a device‚Äôs rating by +1 (or add a function it normally couldn‚Äôt do) for a few Combat Turns, but there‚Äôs a chance the device takes damage afterward. (This quality implies the character often voids manufacturers‚Äô warranties by tinkering, but usually with positive results.)

Name: Wanted by GOD
Game Effect: Grid Overwatch Division has flagged the character as a prime target. The character‚Äôs Overwatch Score accumulates +50% faster than normal (round up) whenever they perform illegal Matrix actions. Additionally, when GOD converges on them, it may respond with higher force (more IC or rapid forensic traces). Essentially, the character is on a most-wanted list in the Matrix, and even minor hacking can bring the hammer down quickly.

Name: Weak Immune System
Game Effect: Poor resistance to disease and infection; ‚Äì2 dice on tests to resist pathogens and toxins. The character falls ill more easily and takes longer to recover.

Name: Will to Live (1-3)
Game Effect: Strong survival instinct; each level adds +1 boxes to the Physical damage overflow track (allowing the character to survive more damage).
